variant.question:
An aircraft, flying at 20°N latitude, executes a laft turn from 045° Magnetic Heading (MH) to 315° (MH). The pilot reads the MH indication from a Direct Reading Magnetic Compass (DRMC). Which of the following should the pilot take into consideration before commencing the turn?
1. He/she should roll out when the DRMC reads 335°, in order to read 315° MH with the wings level.
2. He/she should roll out when the DRMC reads 295°, in order to read 315° MH with the wings level.
3. The turning error of the DRMC increases as the bank angle increases.
4. A timed turn would be more practical to execute; it would take 30 seconds with a rate-1 turn.
5. A timed turn would be more practical to execute; it would take 90 seconds with a rate-1 turn.

options.text: 1, 3 and 4
2, 3 and 5
1, 3 and 5
2, 3 and 4

deviation correction curve.
compass swinging curve.
map showing the isoclinic lines.

variant.question: The purpose of compass check swing is to:

options.text: measure the angle between Magnetic North and compass North.
cancel out the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field.
cancel out the vertical component of the Earth's magnetic field.
cancel out the effects of the magnetic fields found on board the aeroplane.

variant.question: A magnetic variation of 20°W means that the magnetic heading to an object is...

options.text: 115° when the true heading is 095°
175° when the true heading is 195°
115° when the compass heading is 095°
175° when the compass heading is 195°

options.text: error detector.
erector system.
heading indicator.
amplifier

variant.question: When accelerating on an easterly heading in the northern hemisphere, the compass card of a direct reading magnetic compass will turn:

options.text: clockwise giving an apparent turn toward the north.
anti-clockwise giving an apparent turn toward the north.
anti-clockwise giving an apparent turn toward the south.
clockwise giving an apparent turn toward the south.

variant.question: What is the maximum permissible deviation error for a direct reading magnetic compass?

options.text: 5º
1º
0º

variant.question: The "magnetic dip" at any point on the Earth's surface is the angle formed between the:

options.text: compass needle and the local horizontal.
compass needle and the local vertical.
horizontal component of the magnetic field and true north direction.
compass needle and lateral axis of the aircraft during a steady turn.

variant.question: Which statement is true regarding a compass when directly overhead the north magnetic pole?

options.text: the compass tip will point directly down
deviation is 90º
the compass tail points down
the magnetic variation is 90º

What is the purpose of compass calibration?
Compass Calibration is performed to determine the deviation...

options.text: On any heading.
At any latitude and longitude.
Only on N, S, E and W headings.
On a given heading.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct as regards the operational use of a Direct Reading Compass (DRC)? The DRC...

options.text: requires no power from the aircraft systems to indicate direction.
is free from interference from other aircraft systems and components.
is more reliable than a directional gyro during turns and periods of acceleration or deceleration.
is only certified for use under VFR and during published hours of daylight.

variant.question: Direct reading magnetic compass errors are:

options.text: due to north change, depending on the bank angle and magnetic heading.
due to the lateral gusts which occur when the aircraft is heading eastward or westward.
due to Schuler oscillations.
parallax errors due to compass rose oscillations.

variant.question: Permanent magnetism in aircraft arises chiefly from:

options.text: hammering, and the effect of the Earth's magnetic field, whilst under construction.
exposure to the Earth's magnetic field during normal operation.
the effect of internal wiring and exposure to electrical storms.
the combined effect of aircraft electrical equipment and the Earth's magnetic field.

variant.question: A magnetic compass, when used at or close to the magnetic poles will be unreliable because of:

options.text: a decrease in the horizontal magnetic field strength.
an increase in both, the vertical and the horizontal magnetic field strength.
fluctuations in the earth's magnetic field strength.
a decrease in both, the vertical and the horizontal magnetic field strength.

variant.question: The direct indicating compass is no more reliable when approaching: - the magnetic poles. - the magnetic equator with an east or west heading. - the magnetic equator with a north or south heading. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

options.text: 1 only

The direct reading magnetic compass is made aperiodic (dead beat) by:

options.text: using long magnets.
using the lowest acceptable viscosity compass liquid.
keeping the magnetic assembly mass close to the compass point and by using damping wires.
pendulous suspension of the magnetic assembly.

variant.question: The inclination of the earth magnetic field at the North magnetic Pole is equal to:
The inclination of the earth magnetic field at the North magnetic Pole is equal to:
Before a flight, the direct reading magnetic compass has to be checked for serviceability. This is accomplished by:

options.text: Comparison of the indication to a known reference direction (e.g. runway direction).
Compass swinging.
Checking the deviation with astronavigation.
Using the known compass deviation to adjust the indication to magnetic North.

variant.question: In a remote indicating compass system the amount of deviation caused by aircraft magnetism and electrical circuits may be minimised by:

options.text: mounting the detector unit (flux valve) in the wingtip.
mounting the detector unit (flux valve) in the cockpit.
using a vertically mounted gyroscope instead of a horizontally mounted one.
positioning the gyroscope in the centre of the aircraft.

variant.question: In a remote indicating compass system the amount of deviation caused by aircraft magnetism and electrical circuits may be minimized by:

options.text: mounting the detector unit in the wingtip.
the use of repeater cards.
positioning the master unit in the center of the aircraft.
using a vertically mounted gyroscope.

variant.question: Deviation compensation in a flux gate compass is done

options.text: mechanically.
electronically.
automatically within the compass system.
there is no provision for deviation compensation.

variant.question: When describing the Earths Magnetic Field, What is the magnetic Meridian

options.text: Horizontal component of magnetic force lines
Deviation of magnetic force lines
Vertical component of magnetic force lines
Variation of magnetic force lines

variant.question: The horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field:

options.text: is stronger closer to the magnetic equator.
weakens with increasing distance from the nearer magnetic pole.
is approximately the same at all magnetic latitudes less than 60°.
weakens with increasing distance from the magnetic poles.

variant.question: The horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field:

options.text: is very small close to the magnetic poles.
increases with an increase of the magnetic latitude.
is maximum at the magnetic poles.
is minimum at the magnetic equator.

variant.question: The horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field:

options.text: is approximately the same at magnetic latitudes 50°N and 50°S.
weakens with increasing distance from the magnetic poles.
is approximately the same at all magnetic latitudes less than 60°.
weakens with increasing distance from the nearer magnetic pole.

variant.question: In the northern hemisphere, accelerating in an easterly direction, a direct reading magnetic compass indicates:

options.text: an apparent turn to the north.
an apparent turn to approximately the heading 100°.
an apparent turn to the south.
no apparent turn.

variant.question: Complete the following statement regarding magnetic variation. The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to:

options.text: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase or decrease.
an increasing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to increase.
a reducing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to decrease.
magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase.

variant.question: Hard iron magnetism in aircraft may be caused by

options.text: all answers are correct.
magnetic qualities of the cargo or baggage.
steel components, mainly in engines and undercarriage.
a strike of lightning.

variant.question: A flux valve detects:

options.text: Electronically the horizontal component of the earth magnetic field.
Electronically the vertical component of the earth magnetic field.
Vertical and horizontal components.
Mechanically the vertical component of the earth magnetic field.

Steer 359 030 061 092 121 150 178 209 242 272 298 331
 
The DRC indicates heading 242 variation is 22°E. What is true heading of aircraft ?

greatest on east/west headings and at high latitudes.
greatest on north/south headings, and are least at high latitudes.
greatest on east/west headings, and are least at high latitudes.

hard iron pieces.
magnetized needles.
soft iron pieces.

options.text: turning error is due to the vertical component of the earth`s magnetic field.
acceleration errors are due to the angle of dip.
errors of parallax are due to the oscillation of the compass rose
acceleration errors are due to Schüler oscillations

options.text: turning error is due to the vertical component of the earth`s magnetic field.
reading error.
errors of parallax are due to the oscillation of the compass rose.

variant.question: Concerning the direct reading magnetic compass:

options.text: turning error is due to the vertical component of the Earth's magnetic field.
errors of parallax are due to the oscillation of the compass rose.
acceleration errors are due to Schuler oscillations.

options.text: sense the Earth's magnetic field.
command the needle of the direct-reading magnetic compass.
relieve the compressor from excess pressure.
by-pass a blocked filter of an essential system.

options.text: turning the ADF on in flight.
a walk-man headset placed close to the compass.
relocating a steel iron construction in the cargo compartment close to the DRC.
letting a passenger in the cockpit jump-seat put his mobile phone next to the DRC.

impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's TAS.

a freely suspended compass needle will stand horizontal.

variant.question: Which statement is true about the Direct Reading Compass (DRC)?

options.text: Before Take Off the DRC should be checked by comparing the heading to the runway direction.
The DRC is serviceable when the indication is within 2 degrees of the magnetic track on the navigation chart.
The DRC is serviceable when the indication during take off differs by not more than 2 degrees from the runway true direction.
The heading of the DRC can only be checked with the runway direction after allowing for magnetic variation.

variant.question: An aircraft is lined up on Runway 23, which is aligned with a magnetic bearing of 232°M. options.text: Cancel the flight and return to maintenance.
Adjust the compass by -11° prior to commencing the take-off roll.
Continue the flight with no adjustments required.
Adjust the compass by +11° prior to commencing the take-off roll.

is caused by the inclination of the Earth`s magnetic field lines.
varies inversely with the bank angle of the aircraft.

variant.question: An aircraft in the Northern Hemisphere makes an accurate rate one turn to the left. If the initial heading was 070, after 20 seconds the direct reading magnetic compass should read:

options.text: More than 010º.

variant.question: What would happen to the autopilot if the flux valve started drifting off in an aircraft equipped with only a single flux valve? Assume the autopilot is in heading hold mode.

options.text: The autopilot would start drifting off too.
The 'FLUX ERROR' warning light would illuminate on the autopilot control panel, and the autopilot would use its internal logic to compensate for the error.
The autopilot would disengage automatically.
Nothing. The autopilot is independent from the flux valve.
